# Chief Intelligence Officer - Daily Brief
**Topic**: Latest global political and military news
**Time**: 2026/2/17 12:44

## Situation Overview
Welcome to the Daily News Channel, I'm Joe. Welcome to today's global news roundup. In the past 24 hours, the geopolitical and international security situation has undergone dramatic upheavals. From the rapid recapture of 200 square kilometers of territory on the Ukrainian battlefield, to the Trump administration's "June deadline" for Russia-Ukraine peace talks, and the full-scale unfolding of the US-Iran diplomatic maneuvering in Geneva, the world is at a critical strategic turning point. During the closing of the Munich Security Conference, the strategic deployments regarding transatlantic relations, high-level contacts between China and the US, and the Taiwan issue have also become global focal points. This program will provide an in-depth analysis of 20 major events that have impacted global processes in the past 24 hours, offering insights into the complex international situation and cutting-edge technological competition. Please see the detailed report below.

## Key Intelligence
### 1. A major turning point occurred in the southeastern Ukrainian conflict, with Ukrainian forces exploiting a communications malfunction to recapture 200 square kilometers of territory.
- **Time**: 2026-02-16
- **Source**: The Independent, ISW
- **Summary**: According to the latest data from The Independent and the Institute for War Studies (ISW), the Ukrainian army has made its biggest advance since June 2023 in its counter-offensive east of Zaporizhzhia. In just a few days, the Ukrainian side successfully recaptured approximately 201 square kilometers of territory, a scale that essentially negates all the progress made by the Russian army since last December. Analysts point out that the Ukrainian breakthrough was largely due to the disruption of Russian command and communication caused by blocked Starlink access. Meanwhile, British Defense Secretary John Healy pointed out that due to severe combat casualties in the Russian army, Putin is being forced to increasingly rely on foreign mercenaries, whose losses have exceeded mobilization and supply capabilities.
- **References**:
  - [1] [The Independent, ISW](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/ukraine-russia-war-live-map-offensive-putin-zelensky-news-b2921605.html)

### 2. The US has set a June deadline for reaching peace talks, while Ukraine faces a nationwide power supply crisis.
- **Time**: 2026-02-16
- **Source**: CBS News, The Independent
- **Summary**: According to CBS News, the third round of US-mediated peace talks between Ukraine and Russia has begun in Geneva. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy revealed that the Trump administration has set a clear June deadline for both sides, and if an agreement is not reached by then, the US will significantly increase pressure. Zelenskyy emphasized that US pressure must be primarily directed at Russia. US Special Envoy Steve Vitkov stated that the recent successful exchange of 314 prisoners of war was "substantial progress," but a ceasefire still faces significant challenges. Meanwhile, due to Russia's continued attacks on Ukrainian thermal power plants, a nationwide blackout has been implemented, and the humanitarian situation has once again deteriorated.
- **References**:
  - [1] [CBS News, The Independent](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/ukraine-russia-war-live-map-offensive-putin-zelensky-news-b2921605.html)
  - [2] [CBS News](https://www.cbsnews.com/tag/war/)

### 3. Russia's nuclear weapons deployment is advancing toward the EU border; Donetsk's Loveyansk was attacked by airstrikes.
- **Time**: 2026-02-16
- **Source**: Daily Mail, ITV News
- **Summary**: According to the Daily Mail and ITV News, Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, in exile, warned that Putin plans to further advance nuclear weapons toward the EU border following the deployment of the Hazel missile system. In terms of actual combat, Russia launched an airstrike on Sloviansk in the Donetsk region, killing at least two civilians. Furthermore, following the latest findings of the investigation into the Navalny poisoning incident, the UK and its allies are considering a new round of sanctions against Moscow. Ukraine, meanwhile, continues to retaliate through legal means, sanctioning 10 Russian athletes for supporting the war.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Daily Mail](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/google-news-sitemap1.xml)
  - [2] [ITV News](https://www.itv.com/news/2026-02-15/russia-could-face-fresh-sanctions-after-navalny-poisoning-findings-cooper-says)

### 4. The 2026 Munich Security Conference concludes: Clash of ideologies between Europe and the US Republican Party.
- **Time**: 2026-02-15
- **Source**: The Guardian
- **Summary**: According to The Guardian, the Munich Security Conference 2026 concluded on the 15th. During the conference, EU foreign policy chief Kalas strongly refuted US Secretary of State Rubio's remarks about a "wake-up Europe," emphasizing that Europe remains a desirable destination for many countries. Former President Clinton harshly criticized Trump's Ukraine policy as a "betrayal of the West." Despite pressure to adjust US policy, ECB President Lagarde pointed out that Europe is becoming stronger under pressure, but the conference also revealed that the EU cannot currently provide a clear timetable for Ukraine's accession. French officials suggested that future European defense spending should prioritize domestic procurement.
- **References**:
  - [1] [The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2026/feb/15/munich-security-conference-rubio-kallas-lagarde-europe-latest-news-updates)

### 5. Driven by security pressures, Poland is considering joining a nuclear sharing program to counter the Russian threat.
- **Time**: 2026-02-16
- **Source**: Daily Mail, CBS News
- **Summary**: According to the Daily Mail, Poland, a NATO outpost, is seriously considering joining NATO's nuclear sharing program and even exploring the possibility of developing its own nuclear capabilities. This move stems primarily from signals released by Washington at the Munich Security Conferenceâ€”Secretary of State Rubio emphasized that US-EU relations need to operate under "revised terms," meaning Washington needs strong partners, not vassals. Poland's actions reflect the urgent need for nuclear deterrence among NATO's eastern flank members amid the escalating Russia-Ukraine conflict. Furthermore, NATO warships are closely tracking Russian submarines in the Arctic to ensure the absolute security of strategic shipping lanes.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Daily Mail](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/google-news-sitemap1.xml)
  - [2] [CBS News](https://www.cbsnews.com/tag/war/)

### 6. Indirect talks between the US and Iran resumed in Geneva; Tehran expressed willingness to conditionally dilute highly enriched uranium.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: CNN Arabic, Politico
- **Summary**: According to CNN Arabic and Politico, on February 17, Iranian Foreign Minister Araqchi met with IAEA Director General Grossi in Geneva, Switzerland, and subsequently began a second round of indirect negotiations with representatives of the Trump administration. Iran expressed positive signals: the head of the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran stated that if the United States lifts relevant sanctions, Iran is willing to dilute its uranium to 60% enrichment, but explicitly refuses to move the enriched uranium overseas. President Trump is optimistic, believing that Iran is eager to reach an agreement to avoid "serious consequences," but he also emphasized that while diplomacy continues, the United States will maintain high-intensity military pressure.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Politico](https://www.politico.com/news/2026/02/15/iran-diplomat-geneva-00782760)
  - [2] [Anadolu Agency](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/iran-s-foreign-minister-meets-un-nuclear-watchdog-chief-in-geneva-ahead-of-us-talks/3831219)

### 7. Trump and Netanyahu discuss military options; two US carrier strike groups meet in the Middle East.
- **Time**: 2026-02-15
- **Source**: CBS News, CNN Arabic
- **Summary**: According to our station, military deployments in the Middle East have significantly escalated in the past 48 hours. President Trump held in-depth talks with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago. Sources indicate that the US stated it would support Israeli forces in striking Iranian missile facilities if Iran rejects the nuclear agreement. Netanyahu emphasized that any agreement must include restrictions on ballistic missile programs and a halt to proxy funding. Meanwhile, the Pentagon has deployed the USS Ford carrier strike group to the Middle East, joining the existing USS Lincoln carrier strike group to create a high-pressure dual-carrier posture aimed at military deterrence against regional adversaries.
- **References**:
  - [1] [CBS News](https://www.cbsnews.com/tag/middle-east/)
  - [2] [CNN Arabic](https://arabic.cnn.com/news/sitemap.xml)

### 8. The ceasefire agreement between Lebanon and Israel is struggling to hold, and Trump has proposed the idea of "taking over Gaza."
- **Time**: 2026-02-16
- **Source**: SCMP, CNN Arabic
- **Summary**: According to the South China Morning Post, although the ceasefire agreement along the Lebanese-Israeli border is currently largely maintained, an Israeli airstrike on a suspicious vehicle on the Lebanese-Syrian border indicates that the situation remains fragile. In the Gaza Strip, Israeli airstrikes against Rafah and other locations continue, which the US claims are in retaliation for ceasefire violations. Of concern, President Trump recently stated publicly that the US might "take over" Gaza. Meanwhile, humanitarian pressure in Gaza continues to increase, and Jordan has begun establishing temporary camps there. Israeli military operations in Gaza City and eastern Khan Younis have not completely ceased, and the conflicting parties remain in a state of high stalemate.
- **References**:
  - [1] [South China Morning Post](https://www.scmp.com/news/world/middle-east)
  - [2] [CNN Arabic](https://arabic.cnn.com/news/sitemap.xml)

### 9. Intensive multilateral diplomacy is unfolding in the Middle East as Gulf states attempt to mend internal divisions.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: Arab News, Politico
- **Summary**: According to Arab News, diplomatic mediation in the Middle East reached its peak between February 15th and 17th. During the Munich Security Conference, senior US officials, including Lindsey Graham, expressed support for regime change in Iran. Meanwhile, Bahrain and Egypt actively mediated the diplomatic rift between the UAE and Saudi Arabia that has existed since December of last year. UAE President MBZ spoke with Turkish President Erdogan, and although Erdogan postponed his visit to the UAE due to health reasons, both sides remained committed to strengthening regional cooperation. The US, on the other hand, repeatedly reiterated its hope to use diplomatic pressure to push regional allies to reach a greater degree of consensus on the Iranian issue.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Arab News](https://www.arabnews.com/)
  - [2] [Politico](https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2026/02/15/munich-security-democrats-aoc-newsom-rubio-00782638)

### 10. High-level officials from China and the United States held a constructive meeting in Munich, paving the way for a summit in April.
- **Time**: 2026-02-16
- **Source**: South China Morning Post
- **Summary**: According to the South China Morning Post, US Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi held their second face-to-face meeting on the sidelines of the Munich Security Conference. During the talks, Wang Yi emphasized that China and the US should seek a "win-win" situation, rather than falling into a "zero-sum game." Both sides gave the meeting a positive assessment, considering it "constructive." It is widely believed that the core task of this meeting was to clear obstacles for the upcoming summit between Trump and Chinese leaders in April. The two countries are currently attempting to find a buffer zone for stable communication amidst tense trade and strategic competition through high-level dialogue.
- **References**:
  - [1] [South China Morning Post](https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy)

### 11. China is considering establishing a "Made in America Fund" in an attempt to ease trade tensions with the United States.
- **Time**: 2026-02-16
- **Source**: South China Morning Post
- **Summary**: According to the chairman of the American Chamber of Commerce in China, with the April summit approaching, Beijing is seriously considering establishing an investment fund specifically for US manufacturing. This move is seen by many as a significant gesture of economic goodwill from China, aiming to achieve positive summit outcomes through economic investment and thereby alleviate tariff pressure from Washington in the trade arena. While the business community generally expects a comprehensive "grand compromise" unlikely in the short term, the intention to establish this fund demonstrates China's efforts to stabilize the volatile Sino-US diplomatic relationship through structural economic and trade cooperation.
- **References**:
  - [1] [South China Morning Post](https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy)

### 12. The Pentagon's list of defense contractors dealing with China has been repeatedly updated, reflecting contradictory signals in Washington's China policy.
- **Time**: 2026-02-16
- **Source**: South China Morning Post
- **Summary**: According to the South China Morning Post, a recent move by the U.S. Department of Defense has drawn significant market attention: the Pentagon quickly added some Chinese companies to its "military-related list" before swiftly withdrawing the related documents. This rare policy reversal occurred on the eve of the April summit between Trump and Chinese leaders. Analysts believe this reflects a continued contradiction within Washington regarding its policies on sanctions and engagement with China. This uncertainty has injected new variables into the already fragile "truce" in U.S.-China trade relations, leaving global investors perplexed.
- **References**:
  - [1] [South China Morning Post](https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy)

### 13. Experts analyze that the Taiwan issue will become the core strategic point of contention at the April summit.
- **Time**: 2026-02-16
- **Source**: South China Morning Post
- **Summary**: According to the latest assessments of several international affairs experts, the Taiwan issue is expected to be the most central and challenging topic of contention at the upcoming US-China summit in April. With the change of power in the US government, both sides are currently engaging in frequent strategic probing regarding affairs related to Taipei, Taiwan. Experts point out that China's stance on this issue, adhering to the one-China principle, is extremely firm, while the US's new actions demonstrate the complexity of its Indo-Pacific strategy. How this issue is framed will directly determine the trajectory of US-China relations over the next four years.
- **References**:
  - [1] [South China Morning Post](https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy)

### 14. The global defense industry is projected to surge in size by 2026, with AI and digital transformation becoming the core driving forces.
- **Time**: 2026-02-15
- **Source**: Deloitte Insights, Global Growth Insights
- **Summary**: According to the latest forecasts from Deloitte and Global Growth Insights, the global defense and aerospace industry will experience explosive growth in 2026. The market size is projected to grow from $506.9 billion in 2025 to $542.72 billion. This growth will be primarily driven by AI applications, autonomous weapon systems, and digital integration. The report points out that China is exceptionally active in the field of defense technology patents, particularly leading in state support R&D; while the United States maintains a competitive advantage in AI integration and space systems. Due to tensions in regions such as the South China Sea, global naval defense spending has also increased by approximately 20%.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Deloitte Insights](https://www.deloitte.com/us/en/insights/industry/aerospace-defense/aerospace-and-defense-industry-outlook.html)
  - [2] [Global Growth Insights](https://www.einpresswire.com/article/884446254/defense-market-trends-2026-2030-analysis-of-regional-perspectives-and-market-size)

### 15. The US defense budget for fiscal year 2026 will reach a record high of $179 billion, with investment in research and development to disrupt the US's competitive advantage.
- **Time**: 2026-02-16
- **Source**: Performance Software, IFS Blog
- **Summary**: According to our station, the U.S. Department of Defense's budget request for fiscal year 2026 has reached a staggering $961.6 billion, a 13.4% increase from the previous fiscal year. This budget signifies a major shift in U.S. strategic focus: funding is moving from traditional weapons platform procurement to digital modernization. Research and testing budgets have reached a record high of $179 billion. This funding will primarily support autonomous weapons, counter-drone systems, and advanced communication technologies. Furthermore, the U.S. military has begun using 3D printing technology to produce naval spare parts overseas, significantly improving frontline support efficiency.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Performance Software](https://www.psware.com/2026-aerospace-and-defense-industry-outlook/)
  - [2] [IFS Blog](https://blog.ifs.com/defense-industry-predictions-for-2026-expeditionary-reindustrialization-and-the-diffusion-of-ai/)

### 16. The US has confirmed that it will deploy hypersonic weapons in Germany starting in 2026 to strengthen collective deterrence in Europe.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: RBC Ukraine, Babel.ua
- **Summary**: According to Ukrainian media and Babel, citing US sources, the US government has confirmed it will begin deploying a long-range strike system in Germany in 2026. The arsenal for this deployment includes not only long-range missiles with ranges far exceeding existing ground-based systems, but also highly anticipated hypersonic weapons. The US stated that this move aims to fulfill its collective defense commitment to NATO, enhancing Europe's deterrence against threats from the east through "intermittent" deployments. This action is seen as an important supplement to the European defense system and a concrete manifestation of deepening transatlantic security cooperation.
- **References**:
  - [1] [RBC Ukraine](https://newsukraine.rbc.ua/news/usa-to-begin-deploying-long-range-weapons-1720635378.html)
  - [2] [Babel.ua](https://babel.ua/en/news/108899-the-us-will-deploy-hypersonic-and-other-long-range-weapons-in-germany-in-2026)

### 17. The construction of global anti-drone networks is accelerating, and directed-energy laser weapons are becoming a new favorite in defense.
- **Time**: 2026-02-16
- **Source**: Airforce Technology
- **Summary**: According to Air Force Technology, the global defense focus is rapidly shifting towards speed and integration by 2026. Northrop Grumman is currently delivering advanced integrated combat command systems to the US and Polish militaries. Meanwhile, the demand for counter-drone systems has surged due to the proliferation of drones on the battlefield. In addition to portable DroneGun systems, large vehicle-mounted laser weapons and radio frequency directed energy weapons have also been unveiled. Russia's S-500 system has also entered service, with a focus on enhancing its missile defense capabilities. At the recent Saudi Arabia and Qatar defense exhibitions, high-power laser weapons became a core focus of attention for various countries.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Airforce Technology](https://www.airforce-technology.com/features/what-sectors-will-lead-the-defence-industry-in-2026/)

### 18. India and Japan strengthen strategic security cooperation and jointly build an Indo-Pacific defense pillar.
- **Time**: 2026-02-15
- **Source**: The Hans India
- **Summary**: According to the Indian newspaper Hans, the strategic partnership between India and Japan has recently gained new momentum. The two sides are intensively strengthening their cooperation in the security and technology fields. At the heart of this cooperation lies the building of defense capabilities in the Indo-Pacific region, including the sharing of advanced defense technologies and multilateral cooperation on maritime security. This move reflects that India and Japan, as important democracies in the region, are attempting to address increasingly complex geopolitical challenges and maritime security changes by strengthening bilateral and multilateral defense pillars. This development has profound implications for the long-term balance of power in the Indo-Pacific region.
- **References**:
  - [1] [The Hans India](https://www.thehansindia.com/news-sitemap-daily.xml)

### 19. African conflict and unforeseen events: More than 60 extremists killed in Somalia, Sudanese hospital attacked.
- **Time**: 2026-02-16
- **Source**: AP, BBC News, TRT World
- **Summary**: In Africa, the Jubaland coalition forces in Somalia recently killed more than 60 al-Shabaab militants in a counter-terrorism operation, demonstrating the effectiveness of counter-terrorism cooperation. However, in Mogadishu, a Fokker 50 aircraft malfunctioned during landing, overran the runway, and crashed into a beach; miraculously, all 55 people on board survived. Meanwhile, the situation in Sudan deteriorated further, with the Rapid Support Force launching a drone attack on a hospital in Sennar State, causing civilian casualties. Additionally, a ferry capsized on the Nile River in Sudan, resulting in at least 15 deaths. These incidents once again highlight the region's dual vulnerability to conflict and infrastructure security.
- **References**:
  - [1] [AP, BBC News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events/February_2026)
  - [2] [TRT World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events/February_2026)

### 20. Dramatic shifts in US-Latin America policy: Deporting prisoners to El Salvador's mega-prison; pipeline explosion in Mexico causes deaths and injuries.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: CBS News, Reuters, NYT
- **Summary**: According to the Associated Press and CBS, the Trump administration has adopted a tougher strategy on immigration. The US is deporting non-Hispanic illegal immigrants to Panama and has reached an agreement with El Salvador to house deported criminals in El Salvador's infamous CECOT mega-prison. In Venezuela, news of Maduro's arrest caused significant fluctuations in local property prices, leading to a rebound in overseas property demand. Cuba is mired in an energy crisis, forcing the cancellation of the Havana Cigar Festival. Furthermore, an oil pipeline explosion in Oaxaca, Mexico, has killed three and injured six, once again sounding the alarm for the security of the country's energy infrastructure.
- **References**:
  - [1] [CBS News](https://www.cbsnews.com/tag/mass-deportation/)
  - [2] [Reuters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events/February_2026)
  - [3] [New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/section/world)
